- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

```powershell
New-Item -Type File 'test_file'
New-Item -Type Dir 'test_dir'
Test-Path -PathType Leaf *
Test-Path -PathType Container *
```

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Test-Path -PathType Leaf *
False
PS> Test-Path -PathType Container *
False
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Test-Path -PathType Leaf *
True
PS> Test-Path -PathType Container *
False
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> @237dmitry why is it "False" with `-PathType Directory` then?

I think most people would say that behaviour is wrong. Except that it doesn't always do that ..

If `pathtype` is specified  **the first item returned** _before sorting_ determines whether `test-path` returns true or false.  You can get the opposite result by creating the directory before the file. 

If `test-path` gives different results depending on the sequence the items are created, and it seems to, that would be a **bug**

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
> I don't understand why do you expect "false" when there is file?

Expected `True` for both `Leaf` and `Container`. But `True` returned if only single element is in current directory.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> > I don't understand why do you expect "false" when there is file?
> 
> > > I think most people would say that behaviour is wrong.
> 
> Expected `True` for both `Leaf` and `Container`. But `True` returned if only single element is in current directory.


That's not the behaviour. 

- If you create any number of files in an empty folder `leaf *` is true   
- If you add any number of folders `leaf *` is still true and `container *` is false (expected true, right ?) 
**But**
- If you create any number of folders in an empty folder `container *` is true
- If you add any number of files `container *` is still true and `leaf *`is false  

If a mix of files and folders matches the wildcard, the first one created sets the behaviour of `leaf` or `container`

comments.author: k9wazere
comments.body:
This shouldn't have been closed. This bug (or similar) is still present in the latest PS version.
Moreover, the "answer" given in the closing comment is also not correct. LiteralPath is not the default parameter set. Easily verified:

mkdir "blah[0]"
Test-Path "blah[0]" [-PathType Container]
False
Test-Path -LiteralPath "blah[0]" [-PathType Container]
True
"blah[0]" | Test-Path
False

I can't verify the order/date of creation being important but I can say for sure that when a folder and a file both match a given pattern (by using wildcards), then Leaf returns True and Container returns False.

Either both should be True or both False. "PathType Any" will always return True. However using PathType Any is totally useless as it's the default behaviour without specifying the PathType param at all!

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
```
mkdir "blah[0]"
Test-Path "blah[0]" [-PathType Container]
False
```
This is a different problem see #17106

mkdir creates a  folder which includes [ and ] in the name
Test-path sees `[]` as a wild card set and is looking for blah followed by any of the letters in []  so here only blah 0 will match
You need  
```
Test-path 'blah`[0`]'  
```
Or with double quotes the escaping ` needs to be doubled up.
```
Test-path "blah``[0``]"  
```


The behaviour with `Test-Path`  is _If a mix of files and folders matches the wildcard, the first one created sets the behaviour of leaf or container_   As such it has been _answered_ but I'm not sure this behaviour can be _by design_ @iSazonov can we reopen this. I'll take to cmdlet working group, because I can see that people expect that if e.g. 
`Get-ChildItem -Directory *`   returned items `Test-Path -container *` returns true , but I can't see anyone relying on the behaviour relying on the order of creation. (So a recursive copy might give different results from the source depending on copy order)

comments.author: k9wazere
comments.body:
@jhoneill I was simply demonstrating that LiteralPath is not the default parameter set for Test-Path.

If it was, then Test-Path "blah[0]" would return True, not False. I deliberately did not explicitly specify -Path. And yes, I am aware that [ and ] when used with -Path act as wildcards.

I've since opened my own bug 17134.

Ultimately, Test-Path should return True if Get-Item would return a result. It's really that simple, to me. A situation where Test-Path returns False and Get-Item is getting something is totally counter-intuitive.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
@iSazonov   that answer of Dec 3rd is wrong
```
 PS > (get-command test-path).ParameterSets | ft

Name        IsDefault Parameters
----        --------- ----------
Path             True {Path, Filter, Include, Exclude…}
LiteralPath     False {LiteralPath, Filter, Include, Exclude…}
````

The original problem as stated was 
If you have an empty directory  and run 
```
New-Item -Type File 'test_file'
New-Item -Type Dir 'test_dir'
Test-Path -PathType Leaf *
Test-Path -PathType Container *
```
Then the leaf returns TRUE and the Container returns false. 
What I've found is the if the creation order is reversed, then  in another empty directory. 
```
New-Item -Type Dir 'test_dir'
New-Item -Type File 'test_file'
Test-Path -PathType Leaf *
Test-Path -PathType Container *
```
leaf will return false and container is true. 

It seems Test-Path looks at the first matching item for a wildcard search.

title: `Test-Path -PathType $type '*'` depends on some order
